selected_quotes: Nice paper on standardization in reporting/design issues for TMS studies
Important paper on factors to consider/report for TMS studies of the motor system
A checklist for assessing the methodological quality of studies using TMS to study the motor system: A consensus

citation.abstract: In the last decade transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) has been the subject of more than 20,000 original research articles. Despite this popularity, TMS responses are known to be highly variable and this variability can impact on interpretation of research findings. There are no guidelines regarding the factors that should be reported and/or controlled in TMS studies. This study aimed to develop a checklist to be recommended to evaluate the methodology and reporting of studies that use single or paired pulse TMS to study the motor system. A two round international web-based Delphi study was conducted. Panellists rated the importance of a number of subject, methodological and analytical factors to be reported and/or controlled in studies that use single or paired pulse TMS to study the motor system. Twenty-seven items for single pulse studies and 30 items for paired pulse studies were included in the final checklist. Eight items related to subjects (e.g. age, gender), 21 to methodology (e.g. coil type, stimulus intensity) and two to analysis (e.g. size of the unconditioned motor evoked potential). The checklist is recommended for inclusion when submitting manuscripts for publication to ensure transparency of reporting and could also be used to critically appraise previously published work. It is envisaged that factors could be added and deleted from the checklist on the basis of future research. Use of the TMS methodological checklist should improve the quality of data collection and reporting in TMS studies of the motor system.
citation.title: A checklist for assessing the methodological quality of studies using transcranial magnetic stimulation to study the motor system: An international consensus study

author.name: Nick Davis
author.description: Psychologist and cognitive neuroscientist with an interest in 'noninvasive' brain stimulation (TMS, tDCS). I look taller on the telly.

author.name: Sara Hussain
author.description: motor systems neuroscientist. interests include brain oscillations, brain stimulation, motor learning, neurorehabilitation and cats. all opinions are my own.

author.name: Dr Cathy Stinear
author.description: Associate Professor Cathy Stinear is a clinical neuroscientist at the University of Auckland, interested in predicting and promoting recovery after stroke.

author.name: Sue Hunter
author.description: Senior Lecturer at Keele University; Chartered Physiotherapist; CAHPR Keele Hub Lead

author.name: CRE Stroke Rehab
author.description: Australia's Centre for Research Excellence in Stroke Rehabilitation and Recovery. Goals: discover, understand, implement, & train next gen rehab researchers.

author.name: LBRF
author.description: Official twitter page of the Laboratory for Brain Recovery and Function at Dalhousie University. We figure out the brain so you can learn better.

author.name: RIO group
author.description: The RIO group was formed in 2006 and aims to provide a forum to meet and discuss 'Research in Imagery and Observation'.

author.name: Katherine Naish
author.description: Postdoc at McMaster University. Doing science and stuff

author.name: Dr Adam Bruton
author.description: Lecturer/Researcher in Psychology of Human Performance. @_RIOgroup_ organiser. Keen Footballer & Golfer. All views are my own.

author.name: David Wright
author.description: Senior Lecturer in Exercise and Sport Science and Researcher in Motor Cognition at Manchester Metropolitan University. Organiser of the @_RIOgroup_.

author.name: Dan Eaves
author.description: Senior Lecturer in Psych / Motor Control & Learning. PhD in Exp Psych / Cog Neurosci. Researches imitation and motor imagery

author.name: Arran Reader
author.description: PhD Neuroscience @UniRdg_Psych working on imitation, kinematics, and TMS. Mainly tweeting science. All opinions chosen by random number generator.

author.name: Jacqueline Williams
author.description: Senior Lecturer, Motor Control, Victoria University. Research interests: motor skill impairment, particularly in children; motor imagery and action observation.
